Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of male baby (Harpocrates) wearing festival wreath headdress. Mould-made and hollow. White coating. Red-brown Nile silt fabric with abundant mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions. Fragment of upper part only.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Similar Harpocrates figures known from Naukratis (Cambridge, Museum of Classical Archaeology NA655; NA654) thought to date from the late 1st century BC to the 2nd century AD. However, this type has good Ptolemaic and Roman parallels. 2nd century BC parallels from Tell Atrib (Szymańska 2005, nos. 98-9). See also Roman parallel (Dunand 1990, no. 260). Dunand, F. 1990. Catalogue des Terres cuites gréco-romaines d’Egypte. Musée du louvre. Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Paris. Szymańska, H. 2005, Terres cuites d’Athribis, Turnhout.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.074) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5845 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
